question.title: Is there a fail-fast way of synchronization in Java?

node.contents: If you're trying to acquire a lock you have to follow the same contract as everything else working with that object anyway...

astNode.text: If you're trying to acquire a lock you have to follow the same contract as everything else working with that object anyway...

node.contents: @trutheality Good point, thanks.

astNode.text: @trutheality Good point, thanks.

node.contents: If it's OK for you to be tied to the Sun JVM, there's also `sun.misc.Unsafe#tryMonitorEnter(Object)`, as described here: http://www.javaspecialists.eu/archive/Issue194.html

astNode.text: If it's OK for you to be tied to the Sun JVM, there's also `sun.misc.Unsafe#tryMonitorEnter(Object)`, as described here: http://www.javaspecialists.eu/archive/Issue194.html

node.contents: Let's say I have a code snippet like this

astNode.text: Let's say I have a code snippet like this

node.contents: If obj was already locked by some other thread, this code will wait until obj released and after that it will try to get the lock.

astNode.text: If obj was already locked by some other thread, this code will wait until obj released and after that it will try to get the lock.

node.contents: But I want to know if there is any way to jump over the code block if the lock can not be gained immediately?

astNode.text: But I want to know if there is any way to jump over the code block if the lock can not be gained immediately?

node.contents: Or put it another way, is there a way to detect whether or not an object is already locked ?

astNode.text: Or put it another way, is there a way to detect whether or not an object is already locked ?

node.contents: UPDATE：

astNode.text: UPDATE：

node.contents: Thanks for mentioning the Lock interface, but that require programs to obey the same contract, i.e, they all refer to a Lock object instead of the synchronized keyword.

astNode.text: Thanks for mentioning the Lock interface, but that require programs to obey the same contract, i.e, they all refer to a Lock object instead of the synchronized keyword.

node.contents: I wonder if there is a built-in way of checking the locking status ?

astNode.text: I wonder if there is a built-in way of checking the locking status ?

node.contents: Thanks.

astNode.text: Thanks.

node.contents: You can't do it using primitive object locks.

astNode.text: You can't do it using primitive object locks.

node.contents: (OK, on some JVMs you could consider using sun.misc.Unsafe to do this, but that's a really bad idea. You are likely to find that your compiler, class loader or security sandbox stops you from using the Unsafe API ... as it should. Besides, this API is not called "unsafe" for nothing!)

astNode.text: (OK, on some JVMs you could consider using sun.misc.Unsafe to do this, but that's a really bad idea. You are likely to find that your compiler, class loader or security sandbox stops you from using the Unsafe API ... as it should. Besides, this API is not called "unsafe" for nothing!)

node.contents: The java.util.concurrent.locks.Lock API has a method that allows you to attempt to gain a lock without blocking. Specifically, the tryLock() method attempts to acquire the lock and immediately returns false if the lock is in use.

astNode.text: The java.util.concurrent.locks.Lock API has a method that allows you to attempt to gain a lock without blocking. Specifically, the tryLock() method attempts to acquire the lock and immediately returns false if the lock is in use.

node.contents: (There are other higher level concurrency classes that you could use as ersatz locks ... but that's not what they were designed for.)

astNode.text: (There are other higher level concurrency classes that you could use as ersatz locks ... but that's not what they were designed for.)

node.contents: <hr />

astNode.text: <hr />

node.contents: Or put it another way, is there a way to detect whether or not an object is already locked ?

astNode.text: Or put it another way, is there a way to detect whether or not an object is already locked ?

node.contents: Actually, that is a bit different ... and not entirely useful. Sure, you could (hypothetically) test if a lock is being held. (And some Lock classes support this.) But that doesn't mean that you'd be guaranteed to be able to acquire the lock without blocking. If you make that (incorrect) assumption, you've introduced a Heisenbug into your code.

astNode.text: Actually, that is a bit different ... and not entirely useful. Sure, you could (hypothetically) test if a lock is being held. (And some Lock classes support this.) But that doesn't mean that you'd be guaranteed to be able to acquire the lock without blocking. If you make that (incorrect) assumption, you've introduced a Heisenbug into your code.

node.contents: I wonder if there is a built-in way of checking the locking status ?

node.contents: [Assuming that you are referring to primitive locks ... ]

astNode.text: [Assuming that you are referring to primitive locks ... ]

node.contents: No there isn't. At least, not within the running application itself. (A debug agent can do this, but it is not practical for an application to talk to its JVM's debug agent.)

astNode.text: No there isn't. At least, not within the running application itself. (A debug agent can do this, but it is not practical for an application to talk to its JVM's debug agent.)

node.contents: If you want / need to do this kind of thing, you've got no real options that don't involve changing your application's locking mechanism. That's the way it is.

astNode.text: If you want / need to do this kind of thing, you've got no real options that don't involve changing your application's locking mechanism. That's the way it is.

node.contents: you can do it using java.util.concurrent.Semaphore it will allow you more control

astNode.text: you can do it using java.util.concurrent.Semaphore it will allow you more control
